vectorData.altText: H5   Glia of the CNS: Astrocytes

Astrocytes are named for their “star” shape. There are two major types: protoplasmic astrocytes predominate in grey matter and fibrous astrocytes predominate in white matter.
The cellular extensions of astrocytes end in “foot processes” which contact blood vessels (BVs) & neurons.
Astrocytes are rich in intermediate filaments composed of glial fibrillary acidic protein, GFAP; antibodies to GFAP are used for identification. Fibrous astrocytomas (~80^%^ of adult primary brain tumors) can be identified by their GFAP specificity     .
Functions of astrocytes:
The contact of astrocytic foot processes with BVs induces the formation of tight junctions between capillary endothelial cells, which is the histological structure of the blood-brain barrier (BBB)     .
Astrocytes provide structural support to the tissues of the brain and spinal cord. Thus, astrocytes perform the role of reticular connective tissue     in the CNS.
Astrocytes maintain the chemical homeostasis of ECF, e.g. by buffering K+ .
In H03, you will learn about connective tissue (CT), including reticular connective tissue, which provides structural support to most body tissues, other than the neural tissue of the CNS.
Fibrous astrocytes immuno-stained with antibodies against GFAP.
Glia of the CNS: Astrocytes & The BBB

As you can see, the foot processes of the astrocyte take part in the formation of the blood-brain barrier. A barrier that separates circulating blood from the brain and the extracellular fluid of the CNS. 

Further, the astrocytes contact with the endothelial cells also induces the formation of tight junctions which prevent the movement of solutes between the endothelial cells.

The components of the BBB, thus are as follows:
1. Tight junctions of endothelial cells
2. Foot processes of astrocytes
3. Pericytes embedded in endothelial BM
